description: Borrowed from French aspic, from Latin aspis, and possibly influenced by French basilic (“basilisk”). The culinary sense may come from association with the snake due to the traditional colours and cold temperature of aspic, in addition to the fact that the gelatine was often moulded in a shape similar to a coiled snake.

entries.meaning: Aspish; relating to an asp, a small venomous snake of Egypt.

examples: “Put a little aspic in the mould, so as to cover the bottom ···“

entries.meaning: A dish in which ingredients are set into a gelatine, jelly-like substance made from a meat stock or consommé.
examples: "I don't know what you mean, Mr. Wynand," whispered Keating. His eyes fixed upon the tomato aspic on his salad plate; it was soft and shivering; it made him sick.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, poetic) An asp, a small venomous snake of Egypt.
examples: (With that she tore her robe apart, and half / The polished argent of her breast to sight / Laid bare. Thereto she pointed with a laugh, / Showing the aspic's bite. )

entries.meaning: A piece of ordnance carrying a 12-pound shot.
